channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2019 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump Says U.S. Will Hit China With More Tariffs
item.description: The additional 10 percent tariff on about $300 billion worth of goods means the United States will tax essentially all imports from China.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: President Trump had a bilateral meeting with President Xi Jinping of China at the Group of 20 summit in June in Osaka, Japan.

item.title: Stocks Sink as New Tariff Threat Upends Market Rally
item.description: Stocks were heading higher before the president tweeted that he would be raising tariffs on $300 billion of Chinese imports.
item.dc:creator: Matt Phillips

item.title: Support for Impeachment Inquiry Grows in the House
item.description: The trickle of Democrats backing an impeachment inquiry is threatening to turn into a flood, but there are few signs the rising tide will sway House Democratic leaders.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Fandos
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff for The New York Times
item.media:description: Representative Nita M. Lowey, chairwoman of the House Appropriations Committee, added her voice in support of impeachment on Wednesday.

item.title: Biden Defends Obama Legacy After It Was Bruised in Democratic Debate
item.description: Mr. Biden has used his association with Barack Obama to burnish his candidacy, but in Wednesday’s debate that legacy drew some criticism from fellow Democrats.
item.dc:creator: Katie Glueck
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Brittany Greeson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joseph R. Biden Jr. spoke about criticism of President Barack Obama after greeting voters in Detroit on Thursday.

item.title: When Will the 2020 Democratic Field Start to Shrink?
item.description: After two rounds of debates, 24 Democratic candidates are still running for president. There’s little incentive to drop out right now, but August will be crucial.
item.dc:creator: Sydney Ember and Katie Glueck
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Twenty candidates were spread over two nights during the Democratic presidential debates in Detroit this week.

item.title: Only 7 Candidates Have Qualified for the Next Democratic Debate
item.description: While 20 presidential candidates debated this past week, far fewer are assured the chance of doing so again in September.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Astor
item.media:description: It will be twice as hard for the 2020 Democrats to qualify for the next debate. In addition to the seven who already have, three are within striking distance.

item.title: She Was Arrested at 14. Then Her Photo Went to a Facial Recognition Database.
item.description: With little oversight, the N.Y.P.D. has been using powerful surveillance technology on photos of children and teenagers.
item.dc:creator: Joseph Goldstein and Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times

item.title: Letters Show How Osama bin Laden Groomed Son for Al Qaeda
item.description: Osama bin Laden’s son was being groomed to lead Al Qaeda and was seen as crucial for luring younger recruits, who have flocked to ISIS instead.
item.dc:creator: Rukmini Callimachi
item.media:description: A photograph circulated by the State Department announcing a $1 million reward for Hamza bin Laden, son of Osama.

item.title: Dying Gasp of One Local Newspaper
item.description: The Warroad Pioneer, a pillar of its small Minnesota town, ended its 121-year run with bloody marys, bold type and gloom about the void it would leave behind.
item.dc:creator: Richard Fausset and Tim Gruber
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jack Neumiller, 51. “I know everyone I talk to is not happy that we don’t have a paper anymore. I think it’s devastating to lose a local paper.”

item.title: The Economy Is Booming. Or Is It?
item.description: The Federal Reserve cut interest rates for the first time since the financial crisis. We look at what that says about the health of the U.S. economy.
item.media:description: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chief, said on Wednesday that the rate cut was “intended to ensure against downside risks from weak global growth and trade tensions.”

item.title: One Thing You Can Do: Reduce Unwanted Mail
item.description: Also this week, the high cost of the world’s natural disasters
item.dc:creator: Tik Root and Christopher Flavelle

item.title: Is Impeachment Finally Happening?
item.description: And the columnists answer your questions.
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Michael A. McCoy for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protester at President Trump’s Fourth of July event on the National Mall in Washington.

item.title: Marianne Williamson Knows How to Beat Trump
item.description: We need an uprising of decency.
item.dc:creator: David Brooks
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marianne Williamson may have some wacky ideas, but she also understands Donald Trump.

item.title: Why Not Cory Booker?
item.description: He’s winning the debates and he’s great on paper. When will he catch on?
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Frantz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Posters for Senator Cory Booker at a house party in Amherst, N.H., in April. He won praise for his performance in the Democratic debate on Wednesday.

item.title: Joe Biden Is Learning That Liberals Eat Their Own
item.description: It’s astonishing to see other Democratic candidates attack him for his role in their party’s historic successes.
item.dc:creator: David French
item.category: Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)
item.media:credit: Kathryn Gamble for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joe Biden.

item.title: Of Course Americans Are Turning to Social Democracy
item.description: They can no longer afford the luxury of a smaller, less expensive welfare state.
item.dc:creator: Jorge G. Castañeda
item.media:description: A early-20th-century Social Democracy postcard calling for old-age insurance.

item.title: The Republican Exodus From Congress
item.description: Eight Republican House members have announced their retirement this year, with more predicted to follow. What’s going on?
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle
item.media:credit: Illustration by Joan Wong; Photographs by The New York Times and The Associated Press

item.title: Yearning for More Yang
item.description: He is a nonconformist — in the best way — to our political pageantry.
item.dc:creator: Charles M. Blow

item.title: Democrats Are Not Up To Their Historic Responsibility
item.description: Defeating Trumpism means abandoning the politics of extremes.
item.dc:creator: Bret Stephens
item.media:description: Democrats on the stage in Detroit before their debate on Wednesday.

item.title: Videotape All Police Interrogations
item.description: Justice demands it.
item.dc:creator: Saul Kassin and David Thompson

item.title: Debate Disappointment: I Wanted So Much More From Joe Biden
item.description: And I find myself fretting that none of these Democrats can beat Donald Trump.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni
item.media:credit: Kathryn Gamble for The New York Times

item.title: He Was the Face of a Bike-a-thon to Fight Cancer. He Was Also a Fake.
item.description: After John Looker announced he had brain cancer, he became a star fund-raiser and the heart of Pelotonia, a charity event in Ohio that raises millions of dollars. But something wasn’t right.
item.dc:creator: Abby Ellin

item.title: The Bralette Is Back. This Time Blouses Are Optional.
item.description: In an indignant time, a more relaxed style gains market share.
item.dc:creator: Linda Dyett
item.media:description: Joy Corrigan outside the Nana Judy show during New York Fashion Week. Bralettes — mainly defined by their lack of underwire — have become more than just undergarments.

item.title: Despite Deficit Worries, Senate Gives Final Approval to Spending Increases
item.description: The Senate gave final approval to a two-year budget deal that would lift the federal debt limit and raise spending by hundreds of billions of dollars.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane
item.media:description: Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the majority leader, said the budget was “the right deal because it brings predictability and stability through 2020.”

item.title: Indictment Delayed for Father Who Left Twins in Hot Car
item.description: Prosecutors said the investigation into the children’s deaths was not complete, raising the possibility that the charges could be reduced or dropped.
item.dc:creator: Sharon Otterman and Andrea Salcedo
item.media:credit: James Keivom for The New York Times
item.media:description: Juan Rodriguez with his wife, Marissa, and his remaining children.

item.title: Video Shows Last Moments of Dallas Man, Restrained as Officers Joked
item.description: “You’re going to kill me,” the man, Tony Timpa, shouted repeatedly in newly released body-camera video footage. An autopsy classified his 2016 death as a homicide.
item.dc:creator: Karen Zraick
item.media:credit: Brian Maschino for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Dallas Police Department.

item.title: White Supremacist Leader Captured After Escape From Arkansas Jail
item.description: Wesley Gullett, who is listed in court documents as the president of the New Aryan Empire, was taken into custody without incident on Thursday, the Dover Marshal’s Office said.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Jefferson County Sheriff's Office, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Wesley Gullett, the leader of a white supremacist gang in Arkansas, was captured on Thursday after escaping from a jail in Pine Bluff, Ark., this week. Another inmate, Christopher Sanderson, remains at large.

item.title: Justice Dept. Declined to Prosecute Comey Over Memos About Trump
item.description: The former F.B.I. director documented his interactions with the president in a series of memos that jolted Washington and helped prompt the appointment of the special counsel.
item.dc:creator: Adam Goldman and Katie Benner
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:description: James B. Comey, the former F.B.I. director, wrote contemporaneous memos of his interactions with President Trump.

item.title: Jeffrey Epstein Hoped to Seed Human Race With His DNA
item.description: Mr. Epstein, the accused sex trafficker, was fascinated by eugenics. He told scientists and others of his vision of using his New Mexico ranch to impregnate women.
item.dc:creator: James B. Stewart, Matthew Goldstein and Jessica Silver-Greenberg
item.media:description: Mr. Epstein’s ranch in New Mexico, which he confided to scientists and others he hoped to use as the site for seeding the human race with his DNA.

item.title: Wary of Trump’s Hard Line on Iran, Europeans Decline to Join Escorts in Gulf
item.description: The Europeans see risks of escalation in the conflict with Tehran, and they want to distance themselves from the U.S. policy of “maximum pressure.”
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:description: Fighter jets on the deck of the Abraham Lincoln near the Strait of Hormuz last month. European nations are reluctant to join the United States in patrolling the waterway.

item.title: Having Accused a Politician of Rape, She Feared for Her Life. Now, She’s Fighting for It.
item.description: The woman who accused a powerful Indian lawmaker of rape was critically injured in a car crash. Her family suspects foul play.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Hari Kumar and Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: Protesters in New Delhi on Tuesday demanded an investigation after a woman who had accused a regional lawmaker of rape was severely injured in a road accident.

item.title: Scabby, the Giant Inflatable Union Protest Rat, Faces Extermination
item.description: The glowering rodent, long a curbside fixture in New York and around the country, could soon be banned in labor demonstrations.
item.dc:creator: Michael Gold
item.media:credit: Chester Higgins Jr./The New York Times

item.title: How to Answer Tricky Personal Questions at a New Job
item.description: Navigating the gauntlet of questions from the new people in your life.
item.dc:creator: Allie Volpe

item.title: Read Anywhere This Summer
item.description: Summer is the perfect time to rediscover the pleasures of reading. Here’s how scientists and librarians say you should get started.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Reeve

item.title: Behind Basquiat’s ‘Defacement’: Reframing a Tragedy
item.description: A curator’s time capsule of a violent moment and its repercussions brings fresh insights — and reveals stresses with a museum.
item.dc:creator: Siddhartha Mitter
item.media:credit: Estate of Jean-Michel Basquiat, Licensed by Artestar; Mary Inhea Kang for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chaédria LaBouvier, center, organized “Basquiat’s ‘Defacement’: The Untold Story” at the Guggenheim about the reaction of Jean-Michel Basquiat and the downtown community to the death of Michael Stewart. Top right, “Charles the First,” 1982, a Basquiat tribute to Charlie Parker that depicted him as a peer of King Charles I and Thor, the Norse god of thunder.

item.title: ‘Abnormal, as Most Geniuses Are’: Celebrating 200 Years of Herman Melville
item.description: The Times has not always given the writer his due. Here’s a look at how we covered him and his most famous novel, ‘Moby-Dick,’ over the past century or two.
item.dc:creator: Tina Jordan
item.media:description: When Herman Melville died in 1891, The New York Times barely noted it, listing his obituary after a civil engineer, “the best known criminal lawyer in Connecticut” and “the oldest resident of the Oranges.”

item.title: The Frankies Partners Will Open a Slice Shop
item.description: Frank Castronovo and Frank Falcinelli are expanding their Brooklyn campus of Italian-American food.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.media:credit: Daniel Krieger for The New York Times
item.media:description: Frank Falcinelli, left, and Frank Castronovo, friends since childhood, are opening a new pizza slice shop in Carroll Gardens.

item.title: The Yankees’ Trade Deadline Haul? A 20-Year-Old Pitching Prospect
item.description: Yankees management stated for weeks that the team was seeking a top starting pitcher, but it whiffed on its efforts to improve the roster on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said this trade deadline “felt different.”

item.title: And Now, a Bicycle Built for None
item.description: It’s not the first self-driving bike. But equipped with an A.I. chip, it may be the nearest to thinking for itself.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:description: A frame taken from a video by researchers in China shows a self-driving bicycle, whose neuromorphic computer chip helps it understand certain commands.

item.title: Amazon Kindle Oasis Review: Now Is the Perfect Time to Buy an E-Reader
item.description: In an era of smartphone addiction, a single-purpose device like an e-reader may help you unplug and focus on content that will bring you joy.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Cayce Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: Amazon's new Kindle Oasis has a seven-inch screen and an aluminum body, with an adjustable light to shift the screen’s color tone from cooler in the daytime to warmer at night.

item.title: LightSail-2 Mission Shows Solar Sailing’s Potential for Spaceflight
item.description: The spacecraft’s controllers on Earth succeeded in steering the spacecraft, demonstrating that mylar sails could be used for propulsion.
item.dc:creator: Kenneth Chang
item.media:description: An image taken by one of LightSail-2’s onboard cameras, showing its unfurled solar panel sail.

item.title: Colorectal Cancer Rises Among Younger Adults
item.description: These cancers are much more common in older patients. But new data from Canada and the U.S. show a sharp increase among adults in their 20s and 30s.
item.dc:creator: Knvul Sheikh
item.category: Journal of the American Medical Assn
item.media:description: A colored scanning electron micrograph of a dividing colorectal cancer cell.

item.title: All of Those Products Are Making Your Skin Worse
item.description: They’re breaking down the skin barrier and harming your acid mantle, and this is bad (even if you don’t know — yet — what that mantle is).
item.dc:creator: Courtney Rubin

item.title: Hunting for the Real Pasta all’Amatriciana
item.description: Start in Amatrice, Italy, and eat five versions of the dish in just four days. Then set aside your Marcella Hazan cookbook.
item.dc:creator: Stephen S. Hall
item.media:credit: Susan Wright for The New York Times
item.media:description: At Ristorante Archimede in Rome, amatriciana is made with bucatini.
